text: 12oz bottle. Hazy gold with a large chunky white head. Spicy, wheaty nose. Flavors are wheat, grass, lemon, orange, funky banana. Pleasant lingering finish. Very refreshing.
Intense beginning, but dry finish makes it work. Great beer for the patio during the early summer.

Pours up a hazy orange color with a huge bubbly rocky white head that persists. Spicy earthy hop nose with a bit of sweet bready malt beneath it. Taste is mild, fruity with some earthy rustic lightly funky flavors and a bit of spicy hop flavor. Some hint of fruit pulp. Over all a pretty tasty brew.
Bravo hop is showcased here and this beer delivers plenty of it in aroma and flavor, but very low bitterness. Creamy palate. Huge beige head. Sludge pale yellow body.
O+E. Bottle at home. Taste of lemon peel, oranges, apples, tropic nectar, white bread, grass and eucalyptus.
Sample at Jack Browns. Yellow with white head and decent lacing. Smells a little fliral, honey, corny. Light floral blending into lightly bitter. Finishes dry.

Hazy yellow color with white head and some yeast sediment. Aroma has floral yeast esters with some hay, meadow flowers and citrus fruits. Taste follows with floral yeast, slightly sweet at first with some wheat notes, light grassy​bitterness on the finish. Medium body with smooth mouthfeel. Overall its a really nice hoppy Belgian ale.
Bottle from beergium. Hazy gold color. Thin white head. Medium crispy body. Dry finish. Aroma is yeast, spices, hops. Flavour is yeast, light barnyard, roses, hops, citrus.
Bottle from beergium. Hazy yellow with big sugary head. Aroma is orange, yeast, lime, yeast, spices. Very nice Belgian style IPA. Dry aftertaste.
Bottle from Beers of the World into a tulip. Lots of citrus and floral aromas. Very nice.

Bottle from World Beer Market (Sake no Taniguchi). Very fruity, estery nose, quite floral, yeasty and citrus zesty, too. Hazy dark blonde color, frothy head, with a coating of lace, and a lot of sediment dancing around with the carbonation. Sweet malty initial flavor, citrus, peaches, apples. Light peppery hops, which turn a little grassy in late mid palate. Light lingering sweet fruit finish. Very interesting stuff. Aromas are those of a strong ale (maybe a tripel); flavors are more like a saison. Great stuff.

Fleur de Houblon is the kind of Belgian Ale that seems like it only couldve been made by monastic brewers. Its that pairing of old-world taste and timeless beauty. Knockout looks - lightly hazy gold, incredibly good head retention. Funky, earthy, and dank nose. Floral hops and spicy yeast. Flavors are lemony, peppery, bready, and mildly hoppy. Super dry palate. The hops admittedly give Fleur de Houblon a certain American flair, yet it doesnt seem totally out of character for the style. A very complex and lovely beer.

$2.79 bottle from Market Street Wine Shop, Downtown. Pours hazy golden with a massive soft off-white head. Yummy floral aroma - spring flowers, along with banana and spice. Flavor is slightly sweet rose water, banana, more flowers - violets even. Some lemon, some fun, some deliciousness. Damn this is nice.

Damn Im usually not big on Ommegang beers but this one knocked it outta the park. Drank this in the beginning of fall but so with I had found this in the summer. I wouldve gone through a case of it. Aroma was awesome. Peppery yeast and lemon peel were big and dominant with a slight hippiness to it. Pour was a nice light hazy gold with a one finger white head. Taste was like the aroma. Lemony and yeasty with a bit of funk and stale hops throughout. Nice bitter and dry finish. That Ommegang yeast is front and center but not overpowering or bubblegummy. Medium carbonation. Probably my favorite Ommegang beer Ive ever had.

text: Draft at Smithfield Hall. Unclear yellowish-gold. Frothy white head and lots of lacing. Belgian yeast and clove, spice, and citrus fruit. Melon and mango notes. Fairly sweet, yeasty, and spicy taste. Clean, mid-plus bodied mouthfeel. Nice drinkablity overall. Good beer.

Picked up a single 12-oz bottle at Heritage Liquors in Maplewood, Minnesota. Pours a semi-clear dark amber brown colored brew with a thick off-white head that slowly dissipates and leaves behind some excellent lacing. Aroma of golden malt, Belgian yeast, and a touch of earthy spice. Taste is medium bodied with plenty of carbonation. Flavors of hard fruits, Belgian yeast, a hint of candi sugar. Finish has a sparkly carbonated Belgian ale aftertaste with some hard fruits that slowly disappears leaving a yeast aftertaste. A solid Belgian ale overall.

slightly cloudy gold - light amber color with a thick white head; spicy Belgian yeast and citrusy hop aroma; nice, spicy Belgian yeast flavor with saison-like pepper notes with citrusy hop notes; dry, spicy finish; well balanced; very refreshing

Aroma is dusty, fruity, tropical fruit hops, barnyard, banana, good. Appearance is hazy golden amber, off white head. Taste is spice, fruity, earthy and pine hops, fruit, dusty, barnyard, Id say it has a more "in your face" approach than Orval. Mouthfeel is light body, light crisp carbonation, a wonderful dry fruity and piny aftertaste. Overall, this is very very good.

Cloudy golden sunshine with 2 fingers of white lace trailing meringue, disguised as a head. Nose is herbal. Middle is soft creamy grain bill, herbs, wood and earth. Finish is fruity, floral and lightly bittersweet. Excellent beer from a solid brewer.

12 ounce bottle. Pours a hazy honey gold color. Large rocky white head with clinging lace. Floral fresh hop aroma. Yeasty notes as well. Bready, sweet citrus malt flavor upfront. A touch of bitter lemon peel in middle. Dryish, spicy hop notes in finish. Well balanced and refreshing.

Rich malty nose with fruity / yeasty elements. Smooth, slick on the tongue with a sharp, dry finish. Medium body, medium fizz. Floral hops flavor with some coriander and a little pepper. Surprisingly rich flavor. If I were blindfolded, I might call it a yeasty wheat beer.

Love your beers keep them coming. Nice work!

Draft at Moriartys. Hazy gold pour with a karge fizzy/foamy white head. Lots of carbonation. Very strong citrus floral flavors: Tangerine peels. Chanterelle mushrooms. Orange marmalade. Cilantro. Appreciate that this is just marketed as a "Belgium Ale" and not a Saison because it otherwise too bold and fruity. Taken as is - it works.
UPDATED: AUG 6, 2015 Lemon orange nose, nicely carbonated, pillowy head that laces the glass, tastes tart, hoppy, delicious.  Tastes like a Belgian crossed with an IPA. Love it.

(33 cl. BB 03/2016. Dégustation offerte par Vincent. Merci!) Bière blonde traversée par un million de particules. Nez de malts pâles et de blé avec des houblons floraux, des épices, un petit côté banane et une touche subtile de vanille. En bouche, les caractéristiques granuleuses et herbacées ne me plaisent pas particulièrement. Ceci dit, cest loin dêtre mauvais. Les délicates fleurs, le profil épicé et les malts arrivent à point. Au palais, le liquide montre un corps moyen-faible avec un pétillement normal et une texture légère. La finale se fait sur des notes amères peu agressantes mais encore une fois drôlement parfumées par le grain et lherbe.
Cloudy golden appearance. Aromas of bubble gum, and yeast. Taste of yeast, bread and a bit of lemon. Moderately bitter aftertaste.

Bottle from total wine.

Hazy maize pour with a big fluffy white head. Spicy, leathery nose. Flavor brings an enormous dose of band-aid -- this has to be the most band-aidy beer Ive ever had. At first I think "how can I drink this", but then I realize its just what I need as I sit here trying to write on a summers evening: a beer that fits summer but is entirely not designed for quaffing. As hard as I try I just cant fall in love with Ommegangs yeast, but this is an interesting beer and I dont really regret having a glass half full of it in front of me. That said, its so far from a 99th percentile Belgian ale that I fear for the beer-youth of America, even if Ommegang is an old-school kind of overrated.

Pours golden with a foamy white head. Aroma is fruity citrus with floral notes and spicy yeast. Flavor is lightly sweet fruity malt with citrus and some spicy peppery notes and a yeasty finish. Really nice summer Belgium brew.

Bottle. Pours a hazy Amber with a massive fluffy white head. Aromas of citrus, malt, and Belgian yeast--banana and clove. Flavors are citrus with yeasty esters, cut grass, crackery notes and a firm bitterness. Theres a peppery backbone and a clean, dry finish. Lively, well carbonated mouthfeel. Nice summer beer.

BBD 06/15. Hazy (due to yeast) golden pour. World class head volume, lacing and retention.

World class nose of floral hops, lemon notes, subtle clove phenols from the yeast and a biscuit background.

Light medium body with a smooth texture that has just a hint of creaminess. Perfect carbonation with effervescence from the middle on and a rousing prickly finish.

The almost outstanding flavor profile is intense, fairly complex but fails to completely cover the alcohol and lacks enough biscuit to balance. Floral hops lead coupled with a bit of lemon. The middle brings a mild bitterness and subtle and fleeting biscuit sweetness. The sweetness is quickly overpowered by clove with alcohol underneath. As the clove subsides in the finish, alcohol becomes dominate.

Draught at Methuselah, Pittsfield, 6/26/15Very lightly hazed light amber with some burnished copper highlights and a small, white head that recedes quickly to cover.Nicely phenolic nose starts things off peppery and dry while honey and vanilla emanate from the malt, balancing and creating a solid palette for the not-all-that-hoppy hop notes. They are indeed light and playful, adding bits of citrus, light red fruits and a touch of spicy/floral character. It works well, complementing, but not outdoing the yeast while no alcohol or flaws are apparent.Sweet, though not overly so, with soft, honey-like pils malt giving a slightly sticky texture that is then broken up by the dry estery/phenolic Belgian yeast and very minimal bitterness from the hops. Quite drinkable on account of the sweet, easygoing flavors, light wateriness and brisk carbonation. For a beer with the word hop in the name, its not all that hoppy, but for a lighthearted summer ale, it works. Maybe just a bit too much cake/icing sweetness on the finish, with slightly over-doughy maltiness bogging down the palate. Still, clean and drinkable, but the alcohol and tendency towards sweet/malty are a bit at odds with the lighter, hoppy summer session ale intentions here.

The hops that were detected in the nose begin coming in more toward the middle of the taste with the grassy hop flavors starting off the hop entrance and the floral hop then coming in later. In the end a crisp and slightly sour lemon wheat flavor is left to linger on the tongue.

 Mouthfeel- The body of the beer is on the lighter side in terms of thickness with a carbonation level that is slightly on the higher side with lots of little carbonation bubbles. Both are quite fitting for the style and make for a more refreshing feel on the tongue.

 Overall  A crisp, refreshing and flavorful brew. Very enjoyable and great for the summer weather.
Hazy orange appearance. Smell of sweet bread and perfume. Taste is light sweet with slight bread, very nice summer beer

"Damn - they did it again. Hazy yellow, ginormous head. Their bpa is one of my favorites in the style and this follows suit. A cross between a hoppy bpa and a Saison. Pepper, earthy hops, floral aroma, yeasty yet light and refreshing. Delicious, and growing on me w each sip. I hate to have another beer to need more of, but its a good problem to have."

Bottle from BOTW. Huge floral and citrus nose, light spiciness from the Belgian yeast, wonderful. Lemon, grapefruit zest, light bread or crackers. Reminds me of a Westy Blonde. Glowing golden, almost pastel, cloudy, tall fine head, effervescent. Crisp malts, lemony, lightly spicy. A bit tart with a solidly bitter finish. Prickly carbonation, light to medium body. A great hoppy Belgian style blonde. World class.
12 fl. oz. bottle. Pours a hazy orange colour with nice white head. Aroma is straw, citrus. Taste is citrus, straw, spices. Very good beer.

Cloudy yellow pour with a big white head. The aroma has some sweet, banana-like esters, earthy and floral hops, and spicy notes. The flavor is similar, with lots of spiciness on the finish, very earthy too. Good amount of bitterness, and a dry finish.
Bottle, smell is spicy, taste is a spicy yeasty brew, with a nice floral notes and a good clean finish, really full of flavour for such a light beer
12oz bottle.Poured a golden color with an averaged sized head. Spices, citrus, some straw and grassiness. Some fruitiness there too.
Pours hazy yellow with lots of fine sediment swirling about. Aroma is floral with yeast and spice. Taste is similar with more pepper.

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 12 oz bottle into a tulip glass. The label lists the abv at 6.8 % abv and there is a nice short description of the beer. 
Appearance: The look of the body is cloudy and the color is a light golden hue. Its head is tall bright white in color and long lasting. It slowly settles to a thin creamy foam covering which leaves nice lace patterns on the glass. 
Smell: Fleur De Houblon has a classic Belgian character. Pale light grain with classic spicey Ommegang yeast mixed with some light citrusy, grassy and spicy hops. 
Taste / Palate: The nose and tongue are right on the same page. The base is light pale grain with white pepper and clove like spicy yeast. It also brings a light and pleasant Belgian funk/barnyard note to the mix. Hops add a touch of dryness and mild bitterness along with balanced grassy, floral and citrusy lemon flavor notes. The palate is on and very easy drinking. It feels smooth and creamy yet still lively with carbonation. 
Notes: In my opinion Ommegang just keeps on hitting home runs and this is no exception!
12oz bottle. Poured a cloudy golden yellow color. Aroma is light lemon, sweet malt, white pepper notes, straw wheat notes. Flavor was sweet light lemon and straw notes. Tasty and refreshing.

Pours a hazy, glowing honey gold with ultra pillowy, puffy cloud-like head with nice retention. Some yeast sediment floating around. Aroma reveals what is undeniably a Belgian style ale, from their distinctive proprietary yeast strain. Other notes are rose petals, Juicy Fruit bubblegum, mild clove and other earthy spices. Hop element is definitely floral. Tastes like I just bit into a flower petal in full bloom. Peppery and spicy yeast flavors up front are eventually overcome by a pleasant hop bouquet. Nice subtle bitterness and dry on the back end. Good summer ale.
Draft at Hopcat in Grand Rapids. Pours a hazy yellow color. Aroma and taste are floral, citrus, and Belgian yeast.
Only had a few sips of the beer my wife was drinking hope to try it again so I can get more detailed. Aroma is earthy and floral. Flavors are nice crisp and refreshing with yeasty spice notes.
12oz bottle, another great summer brew. Great tasting Belgian, complex flavors, balanced, earthy fruity flavors. Great brew!!

Nice label. 12 oz bottle. Misty, lemony blonde brew. Lemon cough drop aroma -- candied, floral, a little medicinal. Fresh, sweet, zippy. A light but satisfying mouthfeel. Assertive hops that dont overpower. Notes of citrus pith. Very clean drinking. Another good one from Ommegang. ABC Liquors, Betton.
The aroma is very hoppy and biscuit like with floral hops and a wild like yeast. The taste is like the aroma but not something I love. The palate is average. Overall its quality.

Bottle from Winter Haven, FL ABC. Nose is heavy grassy hops, lemon, citrus. Belgian yeast and some spice. It reminds me a lot of Duvel. Flavor is similar. Balanced sweetness with citrus and yeast flavors. Very nice brew.
Tap. Pours a mostly transparent golden with off white head. Aroma and taste of malts, fruit, and yeast.
logging this in from untappd to synchronize all my beers into rate beer for better statistics.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2016 Tap in pint glass at redmonds in Chicago. Hazy gold with white head. Smells flowery with some yeast funk. Syrupy flower taste . Waxy mouthfeel with sweetness, but not too overwhelming. Yeasty funk with waxy sweetness lingers. It?s pretty decent, even though it?s below the standard ommegang. 
Updated after tasting at brewery : much fresher tasting and much better.

Pint at Redmonds in Chicago. Really good value at $3.50. Aroma is super heavy on floral characteristics. Very little head. Light golden and cloudy. Leans on hops but carries the Belgian pale ale torch well. Citrus notes. Refreshing. Actually a really nice beer for the summer. Fleurthy of another try.

Clean, lemony/malt aroma from a pale yellow body with a fluffy white head. Very much in the Saison style with hay dryness and sweet/sour lemon with a Brett bite. Good fresh grain taste with that farmhouse character. A refreshing, delicious, easy to drink summer ale.

Draft. Pours mostly clear gold with with a creamy white head. Smells like bready malts, yeast, pear, light toast, and faint floral notes. Tastes like bready malts, citrus, light sweet fruit, faint toast, and yeast. Medium body and carbonation.

Tap. Pours mostly clear gold with with creamy white head. Aroma is bready malts, Belgian yeast esters, pear, light toast, and faint floral notes. Flavor is bready malts, citrus esters, light fruit esters, faint toast, and yeast esters. Medium body and carbonation.

Thanks HisBoyElroy. It pours bright yellow with a foamy head. A decent fresh springy aroma. Very carbonated and airy. Good summer beer. Just not much flavor and a little too off on the mouthfeel for me.

Poured into a trappist glass, a hazy golden yellow with a large long lasting white fluffy head. Aroma is of ripe fruit, Belgian yeast, light floral notes. Taste is of ripe fruit, pears, some mild spiced fruity notes, a bit of sweet alcohol, yeast. Palate is crisp medium body with lively carbonation which sits well on the palate. The finish is ripe fruit of pears, mild spice fruit notes, Belgian yeast, has a slight dry sweet alcohol ending with mild bitterness. Overall a very good, flavorful and pleasant drinking brew.

Bottle... Poured cloudy, pale, golden-amber with a thick, retaining white head. Aroma of floral, grassy hops with yeast spicing. Full mouthfeel, a little drying, zesty spicing from bot hops and Belgian yeast tones. Light honeydew, grass, and vanilla. Hints of wheat and grains to settle this one out.

This ale has the "glow" of hops around it, from its soft yellow and orange hues to the creamy, bitter palate. Somewhat earthy but with intense fruit and lemon and herbal notes. Really complex and well-finished.
Pours a hazy straw color with a foamy / creamy white head. Notes of yarn, lemon, pepper, custard, orange citrus, and honey. Crisp mouthfeel and long finish.

12 oz bottle into a tulip glass. Pours a clear light yellow, with a big white head that quickly fades, leaving good lacing. Nose is hops and spice, and the taste follows the nose. Short finish with medium carbonation, with spicy hop notes. A refreshing summer drink thats not excessively hopped.
Totally cloudy gold appearance Doesnt smell or taste all that good. Flowery aroma. Just odd

Poured from bottle into skinny tulip glass. Nice hazy yellow color, with thicker white head that sticks around, and some fizzy carbonation bubbles and sone yeasty sediment. Nose has citrus, flowers, a little grass, a little wild/ barnyard funk. Taste is strong on the flowers and pleasant citrus hoppiness. Almost 7%, but cant tell at all. Nice, smoothe palate, not too sharp or fizzy. Kind of not my thing, but definitely a good beer for what it is.

Draft at Barrelhouse 101. Nose is spicy, lightly fruity, yeasty, sweet, with a hint of horseblanket. Lightly hazy gold with a small,lightly lacing off white head. Flavor is lightly sweet, spicy, and lightly bitter.
earthy and sweeter with flavors of banana. softer carbonation, some hop perhaps citrusy. full enough yeasty body a little grain?

Nice herbal nose, very malty backdrop for a range of flavors, including pepper, bread, banana and a general floral note. A nice beer, clearly well crafted, but a bit too cloying.

Belgian Yeasts, Floral & Piney Hops, and a fairly moderate malty backbone with some black pepper notes. Pretty good
Poured a hazy yellow with a white head. Aroma of flowers, light hops, and yeast. Flavor similar, pretty standard Solons Belgian offering from ommegang
It pours a rich hazy unfiltered golden honey hue with a perfect frothy head. An upfront yeasty wheat flavor turns into a citrusy ale with cream notes. Delicious, smooth body
Very light both in color and in body, floral tastes/smells as advertised, also an aroma of pepper and a bright, lemony flavor that makes this an excellent beer for a long summer day.

Bottle pour. Hazy, golden yellow with pillowy white head atop. Minimal lacing. Floral perfume of hops, cut hay, lemon and light funk. Zippy. Medium to light body. Effervescent. Good showing of earthy hops. Peppery and dry. Lemon tartness holds the middle. Bready yeast. Some pear flesh. A small amount of funk on finish. Flavors play a bit rough with each other, but otherwise solid execution. Good summer sipper.

Appearance: bright honeyed gold, lightly hazed, with a huge, fluffy electric white head that slowly shrinks to a thick, creamy cap that lasts for the entire tulip. Aroma: hugely floral, with honeysuckle, rose hips, light marmalade, lemongrass, wet grass, and white pepper.  Taste: 	floral hops are front and center, with nice honey and champagne notes underneath; hint of citrus (orange peel) coriander, and clove. Finish: 	lasting floral sweetness, slowly drying. Notes: Typically overpriced bottle from Gillys in Rockville, MD. However, a typically superb offering from Ommegang. Slick but effervescent palate. Flowery hops nicely showcased, combined with that excellent house yeast...mmmm.

A very good example of the style, extremely floral on the nose, like being in a well kept flower garden with a variety of different breeds, not as light and easy drinking as you might expect from the style and a bit of the herbal quality becomes harsh on the finish or else this would be an unbelievable beer.

Bottle poured a golden color with a huge two finger white head and heavy visible carbonation. Aroma has Belgian yeast, mild hops, flowers, and a touch of sweetness. Mouth feel is light and again there is heavy side carbonation. Flavor has flowers, mild sweetness, perfume, Belgian yeast, grains, and light peppery spice into the finish.

12 oz. bottle, consumed on 6-22-14. Nice, sharp, tart, salty aroma verges on sour. Lemongrass, dandelion, and rhubarb scents. Definitely hoppier in aroma than is a typical saison, but the hops arent overwhelming in the smell. Pours an initially clear, pale gold but later cloudy, light tan. Highly effervescent. Moderate to large amount of substantial, fluffy, uneven, off-white head. Produces decent lacing. Dry, chalky, dusty, dirt-like, earthy, mineral-y flavor features grapefruit and lemon citrus as well as black pepper elements. Quite hoppy. I wish the flavors were a bit stronger. A touch of chemical taste, but not strong enough to detract significantly from the flavor. Dry aftertaste. Light to medium body. Frothy in the palate. Good, summer / hot weather palate effects. Overall, this is a good beer. It is enjoyable and appropriate for the season. It is very much a saison, albeit a notably hoppy one.

Refrigerated 12 oz. brown bottle poured into a Trappist glass. Pours hazy pale yellow with huge fluffy white head. Aroma is floral hops, medium effervescent body, well carbonated, and little lacing. Taste is floral hops, fruity, crisp hops, and slightly bitter finish. Pretty easy to drink.

On tap at the West End Tavern. Hazy golden pour with a nice white head. Fruity esters flowing through the entire beer. Very dry, incredibly clean finish. Basically the definition of a Belgian ale. Delicious.
Tap. Clearish straw gold. Slightly fliral nose. Tastes of pine, some floral notes. Belgian yeast doesnt stand up to hops, but this is definitely a good, refreshing beer.
Bottle. The look is golden in color, white head, and clear. The smell is is white chocolate, butter, grain, perfumed, sweet, spiced. The taste is wheat, butter, white chocolate. Hops, perfume.
12 oz bottle. Gold and hazy with a decent white head. Aroma is of grain, citrus, grass, and light pine. Taste is of malt, grain, grass, citrus, and floral.
12 oz bottle. Pours a hazy gold with a thick white head. Floral and citrus aromas. Nice carbonation. Yeasty, honey, pepper, bread. Finished spicy and dry.

On tap at Winking Lizard Crosswoods on 6/5/14. Clear gold pour with a thick white head. Aroma of coriander, malt, banana and pepper. Coriander and pepper flavor with some malt before a dry, floral finish.

Thin bright white head of fine bubbles with great carbonation. Light citrusy and grassy aroma with some dried flowers, lemon and light grains. Color is a clear bright gold. Moderate bitterness in the flavor with some dandelion leaves, mint, lemon grass and claky grains. Lively in the mouth from all of the carbonation. Finishes dry and slightly citrus bitter. A pretty good belgian summer ale.
Bottle. Pours yellow with white head. Nose/taste of florals, lemon, light spice and peppercorn. Light bodied.

Very nice. Smooth. Floral is the name of the game here, in aroma and flavor. Solid Belgian yeast underpinning. Recommended.

Yeasty honey and bread forward. Taste is sweet coriander. And honey with pilsener corn taste.

Clean floral scent with a background of citrus. Prickly carb, vibrant. Hazy, cloudy with sediment. Few fingers of foam. Sweetish middle on the tongue with biscuit and Belgian yeast. Finishes dry with a floral/earthy lingering effect.

despite the name, not too overly hoppy of a belgian pale. pours beautiful yellow and foamy. aroma like a white wine, and belgian yeast perfume. dry finish and taste like a champagne w/ bitter lemon peel and yeast.

refreshing, but pretty standard. probably is a ton better really fresh.

Nice complex spice aromas, some sour citrus, and candies and some hops. Golden in color, cloudy with a huge white head you can rest a bottle cap on. Rich spicy sweet up front. Bitterness follows that is peppery but smooth. Not really getting the floral hop notes. Nice prickly carbonation an the way down, and the bitterness follows down. Dry but a refreshing summer brew.

Draft at Closed for Business. Clear pale golden pour with a frothy white head. aroma of yeast, citrus, winter mint, bubblegum and pine. Flavor is pretty similar with solid degree of yeast spice filling the tongue. Medium bodied and refreshing. Not bad.

Nicely done summer brew which shouldn't be surprising from Ommegang. 

Pours hazy yellow-gold with a thick, lathery, foamy head. 

Citrusy notes on the nose. Nicely carbonated with a medium body; yeasty and spicy.

Hazy golden orange color with a small, white head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of clove, some banana, yeast, wheat, citrus, and spices. Taste of clove, light banana, orange citrus, lightly bitter hops, and earthy yeast. Dry finish.
Pours golden and very hazy. Grainy head. Tastes little sweet and a little sour ends dry.

Hazy pale yellow, big, foamy, billowing white head, lots of carbonation. Zesty aroma, floral, spicy, a bit of cracker, Belgian yeast. Taste is crisp, slight bitterness, spicy floral note, some grassy earthiness as well. Light bodied, pretty refreshing. Not bad from Ommegang, good for summer. I preferred Hop House a bit more though.
Hazy yellow with a dense skim of white head. Aroma is spices, sulfur, citrus and roses. taste is the same, with less rose notes, and more lemony bitterness.

Ommegang Fleur De Houblon falls short of the hype. Not much aroma coming from this bright golden pour with a nice head. Taste doesnt have the hop notes describe but it has a nice malt profile. Fleur de Houblon is pretty good but not as good as the rating and the pedigree one would expect.
Draft poured cloudy. Smooth tasting of hops with a hint of citrus and spices. Some bitterness but decent drinking pale ale.
Not too bitter for a pale ale. Really drinkable for the strength. Perfect champagne-level of fizz.
Hazy orange pour. Aroma is musty farmhouse. Taste is musty with floral notes. Nice beer.
Lovely easy drinking summer beer. Lots of hops and floral aroma with a sweet and earthy flavor. Easy on the palate.
Bottle. Pours a golden color with white head. Yeasty, malty, floral aromas. Spicy, wheat, yeasty, floral flavors.

On draught at Winking Lizard. The beer is a slightly hazy yellow-gold color with a medum fluffy white head that recedes gradually. Partial rings of lacing on the glass. Aroma of grassy hops, citrus and yeast. Medium-bodied with flavors of floral hops, citrus, malt and yeast. The finish is fruity up front with an earthy hop aftertaste. Above average overall.

Bottle. Pours a hazy golden with a big foamy off-white head. Aroma is very rich, hoppy, floral with a rich sweetness. Full, complex flavor is sweet up front with a dry spicy finish. Uniquely, earthily flavored and quite good. Mild lingering bitterness.
Pours a nice golden color with white head. Floral notes all over the nose, with just a little pine and light fruit; follows onto the palate. Very floral, but refreshing. Dry on the finish.
12 oz bottle pours a hazy golden color with a nice white head. Aromas of floral, bread, light citrus. Light bodied, great summer beer.
This just might be my new favorite summer ale. Nice and light beer with great depth of flavor. Very light foamy head and beautiful light amber color. Delicious!

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2014 Tap at hops and pie. Cloudy yellow with a frothy, clean white head, lasting and lacing. Aromas of spice, lemon, flowers, and bread. Sweet citrus, lemon upfront, spice and yeast on the end. Medium bodied, smooth with a slightly dry end.

On tap at Dexters, pours a clear gold with a thin white head, the aroma has a hint of spice and clove with some wheat thrown in as well, the flavor has some spice and floral touches at first with more of a fruit kick fully in the finish, light mouthfeel, not bad.
Out of bottle on porch. Always to be hazy yellow, quite effervescent. Citrus nose.mix if wheat, grapefruit, and hops in the mouth, some herbs (sage?) Finishes with a touch of funk.
Banquet of aroma. Spicy. Lemonade like body. Fizzy carbonation that fills the mouth. Very nice for summer.

On tap at the brewery, served in a tasting glass. Pours slightly hazy golden with a small white head that fades to a thin remnant and leaves a small amount of fine lace. The nose has big grain, grass and noble hops, along with yeast, Belgian spice and perhaps a touch of lemon. The flavour is mildly dry up front with grainy, pale malts. It quickly acquires a decent dose of hoppy bitterness and this grows to a long and moderately bitter finish with a slight pepperiness. On the palate it is light-medium in body with a dryish texture and soft carbonation. Overall, a fairly simple hoppy Belgian style ale. Light, refreshing, but not the most interesting. 2014-05-03
Clear pale yellow pour with ring of bright white head. very floral aroma. flavor is fruity and floral and refreshing. Moderate carbonation. A little bready. drinkable, but Not amazing or anything

Hazy straw gold with copious white head. Gentle nose of citrus peel, floral hops, yeast spice, and faint "country air." Flavor is semi-bitter citrus/citrus rind with yeast spice. Light sweetness that dries out to a slight bitter carbonic finish. Lingering bitter citrus. Nice light ale.

Pours a very bright lemon rind yellow with a slight haze and two fingers of lacing white head. Nose is dry and floral with peppery/spicy notes and some lemongrass. Some yeasty notes show as well with pear flesh and uncooked bread dough.

Bottle pour. This is a really nice balance of sweet and spice. Heavy on the floral hops.  Some lemon and honey flavor.  Light fruit flavor finish. Very well done summer ale.  Refreshing on a great day.  Loved it.

Bottle- Pour a hazy yellow. With a thick white head. You can smell and taste the floral hops. Subtle crisp flavors, very light on the hops. Fruity and earthy feel. Sweetness from the fruit and spicy earth hints. Very nice summer ale!

Bottle. Moderate to heavy grain and hay for the malt, moderate perfume, herbs and lemon for the hops, light soap for the yeast, with just ripe pears, and hints of honey, ginger and Japanese incense. Head is large, frothy, white with good lacing and is fully lasting. Color is sparkling clear but hazy on the last pour, golden. Flavor starts lightly sweet and moderately acidic, then finishes lightly sweet, acidic and bitter. Palate is medium, slick with a fizzy carbonation. Great fruity aromas and a crisp drink-ability from this Belgian Ale.

Ommegang Fleur de Houblon has a thin, spongy, off-white head, a murky, yellow-orange, extremely bubbly appearance, and some lacing left behind on the glass. The aroma is very sweet, full, yeasty, and citrusy. The taste has the lemon or cumquats, white bread, pronounced hop bitterness, light fruit, yeast, candi sugar, and grain husk. Mouthfeel is heading up towards medium and is carbonated to the hilt, and Ommegang Fleur de Houblon finishes mostly dry, pretty easy drinking, and rich. Overall, another hit from Ommegang. Get some! RJT

Pours a cloudy straw-yellow. Good off-white head--small, but plenty of blanket lace. Lots of lasting power.

As always, theres a ton of Belgian yeast to the smell. Behind that is some pale malt, but its subtle.

More bitter than most of Ommegangs offerings. Again, theres a harsh yeast bite geometry hop in the background, but its not prominent. The aftertaste is better on the hop bitterness, but this still the tale of a strong Belgian yeast flavor.

On tap @ Rattle N Hum. A really big foamed one, and the beer itself is really cloudy, golden yellow in color. It smells of blind Belgian yeast, some green apples, a little spicy touch, some alcohol, apple zest and a little bit of silo fart. Smells nice. Tastes like a proper Belgian. Some yeasty tones and a half sharp alcohol sting. It has a just below average carbonation level and a light oily mouthfeel. The green apple zest sticks in the taste as well, and its what I would call as light mouthdrying. Somewhat watery finish. 13.06.2013

12 oz bottle from Tipsys. Golden orange and cloudy with a white head and visible sediment. Fresh floral hop aroma with citrus fruit, earthy yeast, and light spice. Similar flavor with a medium body, crisp feel and a refreshing finish.

Tap - not much head, pale straw color, light bodied, mild floral hop aroma and flavor with mild sweet malt backbone - not bad but expected a little more

Bottle. Pours golden with a white head. Aroma is Belgian yeast, flowers, frutiness, and a bit of spice. Taste is sweet, but sufficiently hoppy. Aftertaste of yeast and hops linger on into the aftertaste. This is a really well done Belgian ale. It was great after a long run.
on tap @ Excelsior Café-white head with trailing lace-yellow. A-floral, funk, lt malt. T-floral/citrus hops, funk, lt malt.
Murky apricot with a very large quickly dissipating white crown. Aroma is grainy and yeasty with spicy, coriander and grassy hops. Taste of coriander, pepper, yeast and sweet malt.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2015 Smells sweet of Belgian yeast with a bit of a nice hop aroma. Some fruity, maybe banana aromas. Full body in the taste and well balanced. Some Belgian sweet, a bit of hops and some banana nut flavors. All well balanced. Really like this one. Very drinkable. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Great appearance, huge bubbly white head, that held for a long time, and has great lacing. The smell was citrusy and earthy but thats about it. Taste is interesting. Heartburn after 4 big sips. Very lithely hoppy, tons of citrus, and a nice yeasty character. Mouthfeel is a tad thin, and mildly efflorescent.

Bouteille de 12 oz achetée chez Beverage Warehouse (Winooski, VT). Arôme: Odeur dagrume avec une pointe de fruits tropicaux. Apparence: La couleur est blonde légèrement voilée avec une très faible densité de bulle. Présence dun large col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût dorange avec une pointe de citron et dananas. Longue durée de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement onctueuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence dorange en arrière goût. (Rating #5209)
Intriguing hop aroma accompanies the fresh hop flavor. Delicate malt backbone balances this brew well. Clean finish.
Draft. Bright light gold with no head. Light nose of Belgian yeast and mild hops. Light body but flavors are delicate.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Bottle. Hazy golden color. Medium head. Sme lace. Aroma is a slightly sweet, floral smell. Taste is a light floral taste with underpinnings of hay and a touch of funk.

Tap. Hazy golden. Frothy white head. Nice lacing. Aroma of flowers, go figure, and soft citrus and tropical fruits. Taste is malty and a little fruity, a touch yeasty, and moderately bitter. Medium bodied and dry.

Bottle shared at a tasting at Ariels place. Pours light yellow hazy with a huge head, aroma of hops, lemon, grass and yeast, flavor is bitter with hops, yeast, lively carbonation, some lemon tones, medium bodied

12oz bottle. Pours a lightly hazed, light golden body with a tall, frothy, white head. Smells fruity, citrusy, and floral with spicy and subtle resinous pine, with yeast and sugary bread dough. Taste has a moderate wheat malt sweetness with a medium hops bitterness. Some hops flavor and a fair amount of spice and fruit from the yeast. The balance is slight bitter and the finish is medium-dry. The aftertaste is of some spice and citrus. Medium body, with smooth higher carbonation.
Quite strong in hops but not so Belgian. Nice to dirng and a little bit gassy. NIce in overall.

12 oz bottle from FLBC. Pours semi-hazy yellow, foamy white head. Lacing is the the same. Aroma is spicy, lemon, summer freshness. Flavor is nicely dry, a little bitter on the finish, deeply complex, and quite quaffable. Another excellent beer from OMAGN.

My starter beer for before our Old ale and BW tasting .. . Draft @ the Houston Flying Saucer .. . Pours a deep gold, foam and lacing are strong .. . Yeast, bitterness, dry peach skin, and dry hay .. . on the drier side but very quaffable .. . Quite the awesome brew .. . . chips on rolls!

Clear golden with a generous foamy white head. Nose has a lot of yeasty peppery esters, with a backing aroma of Saaz hops and brie cheese. Flavor is peppery and grassy at the start with a clean but assertive Saaz hops and pale cereal tone, relinquishing into a semi-dry and clean biscuity malt and dusty finish. Ends with a quiet grassy/peppery hop twang. Very nice.
12oz bottle. Golden ale. Aroma of floral hops. Dry, bready nose. Airy flavor, light pale malt, crisp straw-like finish. Very light, easy summer ale. (3826)

On draft. Pours a hazy, very pale golden with a thin eggshell head that leaves some spotty lace. Nose involves soft floral notes, spice, belgian yeast, dust, and honey. Fairly sweet flavor, lightly tart, with a fair bitterness. Lighter side of medium bodied, slightly oily and syrupy, pretty actively carbed and tingly, with drying long yeasty spice finish. An enjoyable brew, nice balance of complexity and refreshment.

Bottle from Malt & Vine. Pours translucent gold with a 3 finger foamy white head. Aroma is fruity esters with a hint of a tripel ale. Maybe its all the same. As the foam recedes it smells much like a very floral tripel. Med body or better. Flavor is surprisingly light - not much like a tripel now - theres fruit ester, and some very earthy floral hop. Even getting a little bubble gum. Complex for a "light" ale. Finishes dry and earthy.

Bottle shared thanks to stevencon! Pours a slightly hazy golden yellow with lots of fluffy white head. Aroma is Belgian yeast, chalkiness, and grass. Taste follows, floral notes from the hops, slightly bitter. Not too bad.
Bottle. Straw beer with a big off-white head. Yeast and citrus aroma. Yeast and citrus flavor with light earthiness. Medium bodied. Citrus and yeast linger with light spice.

Pours a slightly hazy golden yellow with a nice ivory head. Sweet fruit, mostly apple and pear, dominates the aroma, which has a malty undertone and floral hints. Flavor starts with a malty core and adds fruity, floral and subtle yeasty notes on a somewhat sweet and slightly hoppy taste. Smooth texture has OK thickness and fizz. Like flowers in your mouth? Get on the outside of a crater.

Bottle sample at a tasting at Ariels place. Thanks zvikar. Cloudy blond. Vanilla hand lotion aroma then grass blades and louisa. Almond bitterness and also soapy-sweetness. Smooth, medium body, bitter yeasty finish.

Bottle at craft ale house. Pours clear yellow with a big white head, tons of carbonation in the glass. The aroma is big lemon, some spicy peppery notes, some yeast notes. The taste is light, crisp, easy to drink. The profile has lemon and orange peel. Good beer.

A steady pour into my Sierra Nevada IPA glass produces a one finger thick, pale, off-white colored head. The beer is a nice gold color that shows a hazy, straw-gold hue when held up to the light. The aroma has a solid herbal / floral note and also has a yeast derived spiciness that leans towards earthy spices, clove, and perhaps a touch of coriander. Soft fruit notes of honey-dew melon, pear, and perhaps some kiwi like character are balanced by an almost woody pepper note, a musty herbal character, and a general woodiness towards the finish.

This has a spritzy carbonation to it, and is quite light bodied and refreshing on this hot summers day. There is a soft Meyer lemon zest character and hint of tartness up front, while an herbal and spicy character lingers throughout the palate. A soft, chewy grain character adds a nice, noticeable backbone to the flavor; it contributes notes of saltine crackers, straw like grain, and, along with the hops, a dried floral character that has lots of wildflower spiciness and grassy character to it. The grain character contributes a soft chewy sweetness that accentuates a green, ripe, fruit character that suggests at pears and melons perhaps.

This is quite nice and easy drinking, I love the mix of herbal / lemony hops, the pale grain character and the characterful yeast character. Once again I find I am a sucker for beers that are nicely hoppy, and not so high in alcohol, that it gets in the way of the dance of malt, hop, and yeast character. In the end this is far more tasty than I was expecting.

I poured a 12oz bottle into a tulip glass. It was bottled on 4/10/13 and cost $3.99 ($0.33 per ounce).

Appearance: A bright yellow, akin to a lemon skin. Cloudy, but plenty of visible carbonation. Forms a huge, bright white, fluffy head similar to Duvel. It retains and laces quite well.

Smell: Classic Belgian yeast esters, plus flowers, a hint of spice, and some citrus.

Taste: The best way to sum up Ommegang Fleur de Houblon would be a cross between a Belgian pale ale and an American pale ale. Its got the base Belgian character down pat: the yeast character with its esters and spicy flavors, along with significant (but restrained) hop flavor and bitterness. 

The palette begins like a lot of standard Belgian pale ales (or "singles"): dry bitterness, some lemon zest and fruit flavors, followed by true hop character at the apex. The label indicates its "hopped to perfection" with whole cone Bravo hops, but if youre expecting an all-out hop bomb you may be a bit disappointed. The hops here add a light flowery component as well as some dry spicy character as well. I get a hint of ground black pepper on the finish, plus a bit more lemon rind or grains of paradise sort of taste (though its nowhere near being a generic American pale wheat ale).

Drinkability:. The mouthfeel is classic Belgian in every way with fine, scrubbing carbonation bubbles, though its pretty easy to get down. While Fleur de Houblon is rather bitter and dry, it does leave a fairly clean aftertaste, though I wouldnt describe it as a refreshing beer per se. Im not sure why they opted for a hefty weight of 6.8% ABV, but then again Ommegang rarely brews small, sessionable beers, so I guess a summer seasonal from them would be rather strong (thankfully, it doesnt feel or drink like something that big).
